Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Situation2: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Story: I stared at the clock above the register, its hands crawling toward closing time. My mentor’s words echoed in my mind: “I want to see your code sample before our next meeting.” Three days. I’d barely started, and every minute at work felt like time stolen from my assignment. The line of customers snaked past the candy racks, and I forced a smile as I greeted the next person. She slammed her items on the counter, her voice sharp and impatient. “Why is this taking so long?” I apologized, trying to stay calm, but my thoughts kept drifting to the unfinished code waiting for me at home. I knew my mentor expected me to show initiative and deliver quality work, but right now, my manager expected me to be the model cashier—cheerful, patient, unflappable. My hands shook as I counted change, my mind torn between the demands of my future and the needs of the present. I could feel the pressure mounting, the two worlds pulling me in opposite directions, and I didn’t know how I could possibly meet both expectations.
